loans.name: Zulekha

texts.en:
Zulekha has been married to Rashid for many years. They have three children, two of whom are in school while one is still young. 

Zulekha has her own business selling juice from her home . Thanks to the work that she is doing, she is educating their children and they buy all of the necessities for their home. 

She seeks this loan to buy fruit, water, flavors and sugar to continue to meet the demands of her customers.

loans.use: to buy fruits, water, flavors and sugar.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy poultry.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema, 23, is a single, beautiful, enterprising lady who lives with her parents in the town of Kisauni. Rehema is a skilled person, who, four years ago, decided to open her own beauty salon. She provides beauty services in her community. She does haircuts, styling, coloring, straightening, manicures and pedicures. 

She is currently requesting her first loan for KES 15,000 to stock up on hair color and shampoo, and rent a bigger place for her operations. She’s very well known by the people in her community and they prefer her because of the good work she does. 

Her goal is to expand the business, acquiring more customers to improve income. She thanks Yehu and Kiva for the financial support she is receiving and she hopes it will be of great help to her.

loans.use: to stock up on hair color and  shampoo, and rent a bigger place for her operations.

loans.name: Kipkorir

texts.en:
Kipkorir is a twenty-four-year-old farmer in Litein area in Kenya. He has been in farming for four years; he produces tea and milk to sell to the local market in his area.

Kipkorir has requested 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy milk pails in order to be able to supply his milk produce easily. This will boost his income and help him in improving his standards of living. Kipkorir however says that diseases and animal feeds are his main challenges.

He also thanks Juhudi for giving him the loan.

loans.use: To buy milk pails.

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
Safia is 37 years old and is a married, energetic woman. She is a tailor by profession. She is very well known for her tailoring work as she has been serving the community for the last twenty years. She has introduced a lot of new designs and techniques in her work that made people admire her. 

Despite all this, Safia was not satisfied with her business approach; she wanted to expand it by getting more stitching machines and labor to spread her unique work to the other parts of the city. For that purpose she needed finance that was provided by Kashf Foundation after evaluating her current business. At the first stage of the business expansion, she took a loan from Kashf and managed to purchase two new stitching machines and also hired two skilled women to work for her. 

Now she has requested a loan of PKR 10,000 to buy raw materials such as cloth, threads, buttons etc. to meet the increasing demand. At present she is happy and has reached the first stage in the achievement of her goal.

loans.use: To buy raw materials such as cloth, threads and buttons.

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business making and selling foodstuffs at the market. She has three years of experience and she says that her business has been slowly growing. Riziki has uncountable customers who prefer her products because of their high quality.

She is borrowing KES 40,000 through Yehu to purchase additional ingredients to make snacks to sell. Riziki has been sustaining her business activities through the support of her husband who is a teacher. She dreams of saving enough money to open a hotel (restaurant).

loans.use: to purchase ingredients to make snacks to sell

loans.name: Secret

texts.en:
Secret is a 28 year old high school graduate, married with three children.  Her children are between the ages of  5 and 14.  They attend school and live in Congo town.  

Her husband is a teacher.  He gave her the initial capital needed to start her business, selling country cloth in the market.  Secret has been in business for four years.  Her favorite part of her business is when customers buy, and the profits she generates helps her buy more goods to improve her business and to educate her children. 

Secret is requesting a loan to purchase more country cloth. Her future plan is to educate her children and build house.

loans.use: to purchase more country cloth.

loans.name: Iddi

texts.en:
Iddi used the previous loan to buy maize to sell. He is a 38-year old married man with four children living in Kamwenge, Uganda. He owns a produce store that he started five years ago. He started his business with six hundred thousand shillings and now it is worth two million and five hundred thousand shillings. His biggest challenge is price fluctuations and inflation while his dreams are to educate his children, buy land to grow crops and expand his business into new markets.

Iddi is requesting the loan to buy maize to sell.

loans.use: to buy maize to resell.

loans.name: Azizfatima

texts.en:
Ms Azizfatima is a 47-year-old married woman. She beautifully does hand embroidery on shawls in a very successful manner. She made the decision to start a business herself two years back when she found her family in misery. Her husband is a driver and but his income is insufficient to cover family expenditures alone. Due to the lack of finance, she decided to approach Kashf Foundation and managed to avail herself of a loan to initiate her business activity. Though she had a little income from of her small business, she was able to contribute to the household's economic activities.

After the successful completion of her 1st loan with Kashf Foundation, now she has taken her 2nd loan of PKR. 13,000 which is relatively higher than the previous one. By getting new loan she is able to buy stocks of wool and threads in various colors. She is a mature business woman because she has learn a lot from one year’s business experience. She is keen to expand her business further because she has set many goals ahead for herself.

loans.use: To buy stocks of wool and threads in various colors.

loans.name: Isra'a

texts.en:
Due to cultural reasons Isra'a prefers that her photo is not on the Internet; thus the above photo is of her sponsor.

Isra'a is a 26-year-old married woman who has two family members. She is from Al Koorah, Jordan. She is requesting a loan of 400 JOD to pay for her home improvements; she would like to buy new electronics.

Since Isra'a is under 30 years old, her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for home improvements.

loans.name: Kausar

texts.en:
Kauser is 39-year-old married woman. She is currently running a general store that she opened a year ago. She works in her store for long hours, seven days a week so she can contribute to the household income which is insufficient to meet the family needs. She has four children and her husband makes a living as a daily worker. There were days when he could not find work and had to return home without any money. His heart was heavy with the burden of facing his family’s disappointed faces. Kauser’s children often slept without having any food. 

When Kashf’s loan officers found Kauser in these circumstances they informed her about micro finance and the facilities they had to offer. The idea of borrowing from Kashf and starting their own business was appealing to the couple. They borrowed consecutive loans to progressively expand the amount and range of items in the shop. Now she has requested for a loan of PKR 15,000 to purchase grocery items like eggs, spices, pulses, etc.  While speaking to a loan officer at Kashf, she said her children have never slept without having a meal ever since she started her general store.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items like eggs, spices and pulses.

loans.name: Neomie N

texts.en:
Neomie, aged 21, lives in Congo town with her husband. She sells slippers on the open square of the market. She received the initial help from her  brother to start in this business. She learned to sell from a friend. She makes profits when she sells, and with the profits, she buys goods to improve her business and improve her life. 

She is requesting  this loan to purchase more ladies slippers, and children slippers for the business. Her plan for the future is to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more ladies slippers, and children slippers for the business.

loans.name: Ibtisam

texts.en: Due to cultural reasons, Ibtisam prefers that her photo not be on the Internet. Thus, the above photo is of her husband. Ibtisam is a 32-year-old married woman who has six family members. She is from Al Koorah, Jordan. She is requesting a loan of 400 JD to pay for her home improvements. She is planning to add another room. In the future, she hopes to buy electronics and repaint her home

loans.use: to pay for her home improvements

loans.name: Banzragch

texts.en:
Banzragch is 22 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a ger (tent) in Arhangai province, Mongolia.  His wife, Altantuya, is 22 years old and daughter, Ariunbilegt, is two years old.  His son, Aldarbilegt, is age one. 

Banzragch started a organic dairy production trade in 2012 with his wife.  He is planning to expand his business. He is a open minded and hardworking person.  He needs 1300000 MNT to purchase more organic curds from sour milk and organic Koumiss (a beverage of fermented mare's milk made originally by the nomadic peoples of central Asia).

loans.use: to purchase more organic curds from sour milk and organic Koumiss.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy another buffalo.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is 40 years old married with three children. She is in the electronics and M-pesa business and has been in operation for the last seven years.  She earns about KES.30,000 monthly.  This is Veronica’s second loan of KES.60,000 with KADET LTD.

She will use it to purchase electronics gadgets. She plans to use the anticipated profits to pay her children fees and save some to buy a plot in town. 

Veronica hopes and dreams to buy a plot in town and built a house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase electronics gadgets.

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida, 43, lives with her two children in a suburban neighborhood in Mombasa.  She is widowed and a hardworking woman who struggles to provide for her children. 

Farida has been selling fruits and vegetables for the last 5 years.  She has a sales stand in a market in the town where he sells bananas, oranges, green chilies, tomatoes, cabbage, potatoes, onions and more at retail. 

In order to stock up she needs a 20,000 KES loan to buy more vegetables and fruits.  Farida hopes to increase her sales and income to support her children’s schooling and to do some home improvements. 

Farida has the urge to move forward despite the adversaries she is undergoing.  She hopes to have a bigger store in the future.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables and fruits.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys, 36, has three children; she lives in the municipality of Mombasa, Kenya, with her children and her husband. She has her own clothing and handbags sales business. She’s been in business three years. She sells her merchandise door-to-door. 

She will use the loan she’s requesting to stock up on clothes and handbags. She hopes to increase her income and clientele. Her dream is to make the business grow to generate income to improve her and her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: to stock up on clothes and handbags.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy bangles for selling

loans.name: Davaadalai

texts.en:
Davaadalai is 22 years old and lives with his wife in a ger (tent) in Arhangai province, Mongolia.  His wife, Lhagvasuren, is 21 years old. She sells clothes. Her salary is 300 000 MNT at monthly. 

Davaadalai finished a computer and computer tool repair course in 2011 and he started to work in a repair center in town in 2011.  He is planing to begin his own printing house.  A printing house is needs by the people in town.  He hopes to have many customers.  He is an open minded and hardworking person. 

He needs 1800000 MNT to purchase a printer to start his business.

loans.use: to purchase a printer to start his business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy another dairy cow.

loans.name: Dorjderem

texts.en:
Dorjderem is 31 years old who lives with his wife and 2 daughters in small house, in Arhangai province, Mongolia. 

He and his wife are cooks.  Dorjderem has worked in a cafe since 2007.  Him and his wife have been operating their own cafe since May of this year.  His business is continuing normally.  They have one employee at a cafe. 

He is requesting 4,000,000 MNT to buy new equipments and additional tables and chairs for cafe.  They want to open their own restaurant. He is a very communicative person.

loans.use: to buy new equipments and additional tables and chairs for cafe.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy better quality fertilizers, seeds.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia requests a new loan to buy bread, beverages, flour and other products needed to stock her store.  She wants to continue growing and providing customers with everything they need. 

She is a hard work and made sacrifices to improve her business.

Lydia also plans to get electricity installed in her house which will help her sell during late evenings.  This way, she will earn more profits, which will help her increase her income.

loans.use: to buy bread, beverages, flour and other products needed to stock her store.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides for agriculture business.

loans.name: Sobhi

texts.en:
Sobhi is 21 years old and is from Gaza. He owns a small grocery store.

Sobhi asked Ryada for this youth loan in order to buy more goods for his store and install display shelves. He hopes that this loan will help him improve his income and help him save money for the future.

loans.use: to buy more goods for his store and install display shelves.

loans.name: Shadi

texts.en:
Shadi is 33 years old and from Gaza. He owns a shop for selling cosmetics and perfumes for ladies.

He asked Ryada for this loan in order to buy an air conditioner and change the decoration of the shop. He hopes that this loan will help him improve his income to help him settle down and fulfill his dreams of getting married and having children.

loans.use: to buy an air conditioner and change the decoration of the shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a chuff cutter.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy goats and sheep for animal sales business.

loans.name: Mardea

texts.en:
Mardea, 25, is married with a child that is two years of age. 

She is a university student, and lives at Congo town.  Her  husband is a barber,  For the past six years she has been selling used clothes, she sells both boys and girls clothing.  A challenge she face is low sales during the raining season. 

She make profit when she sells and with the profit she buys more goods to resell.  Her favorite part of her business is during the charisma season, when her sales are very high.  

Mardea requests a loan to purchase more used clothes for the business.  Her plan for the future is to have a boutique, and to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for the business.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Ms. Amina is a 27-year-old married mother of two who financially helps her family. Her husband is employed as a salesperson, but his income is insufficient to support the family members alone.

Almost two years ago, Ms. Amina took the initiative in her area and started an academy that offers educational services to poor students at cheap rates so they can have a better future. She is satisfied by doing this sort of business as it is beneficial for her household and society as a whole. 
 
Ms. Amina has taken several loans from Kashf Foundation to cover the cost of rent and books for the children. Now she is in her second loan cycle and requires 30000 PKR to buy furniture for the academy to accommodate more students. She is hopeful to have more students in her academy in the coming days.

loans.use: to buy furniture to accommodate more students at her academy.

loans.name: Marwa

texts.en:
Marwa is 26 years old and is from Gaza. She owns a beauty salon, and her goal is to own one of the biggest beauty centers in the area.

Marwa asked Ryada for this youth loan to buy an electricity generator and change the decorations in her salon. She hopes this loan will help her improve her income to help her achieve her dream of owning her center.

loans.use: to buy an electricity generator and change the decorations in her salon.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose has been a businesswoman for several years. She has been operating businesses involving water and a vegetable stall. This is the second loan she is requesting from Kiva and Yehu. Rose promises to make her payments on time so as to ask for more loans to grow her businesses. She has had a good repayment history since she was able to repay her first loan and therefore there is no doubt that she will repay this current loan she is requesting. Thanks to the loans she is getting, she has been able to improve her living standards. With this loan, she will be able to open a food stall and purchase some ingredients like wheat flour, rice, sugar, and oil.

loans.use: to open a food stall and purchase some ingredients like wheat flour, rice, sugar, and oil

loans.name: Kaneez

texts.en:
Kaneez is a 46-year-old ambitious lady with six children. Her husband has a low income, which is insufficient to meet the family expenditures. So she decided to help her husband in financial matters.

Kaneez started making beds and chairs with nylon and rope. She has been in the business of making furniture for 30 years. She is struggling hard to support her family and is motivated to fulfill their daily needs. 

Kaneez requires Rs. 25,000 to buy bulk nylon, ropes, and wooden frames to increase her sales of furniture. She is hopeful to get more income through her sales. She dreams of providing her children with quality education and good health.

loans.use: to buy bulk nylon, ropes, and wooden frames to increase her sales of furniture.

loans.name: Ismael

texts.en:
Ismael is 26 years old and is from Gaza. He is married and has owned a barbershop since 2005.

Ismael asked Ryada for this youth loan in order to buy a new barber chair and change some of the decoration in the salon. He hopes that this loan will help him increase his customers and improve his income.

loans.use: to buy a new barber chair and change some of the decoration in the salon.

loans.name: Trang

texts.en:
Trang, a 45 year-old married woman with two children, lives in Ho Chi Minh City. Her husband works as a carpenter, while Trang runs a food stall that sells a variety of food to people in the local community. She started this business three years ago.

Trang is requesting a loan to purchase more good quality food and ingredients to make better dishes to sell from her stall. She hopes that this will enable her to attract more customers to her stall. She also hopes her business will run smoothly and she can earn additional income to reinvest in her stall and save for emergencies.

loans.use: to buy food and ingredients to make better dishes to sell from her stall.

loans.name: Famata

texts.en:
Famata is 40 years old and lives in Sinkor. She is single and has a 2-year-old child who lives with her. For 2 years, Famata has been selling clothes in the market; she started this business with her Susu (the Liberian way of saving money). She says it helps her to earn her own money.

Famata is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes for her business. She wants to be a successful businesswoman and earn her money.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Lien

texts.en:
Lien is 45 years old and is married with one son and one daughter. She and her husband have been running a shop selling gas tanks for 12 years. They live in Ho Chi Minh City.

Lien is requesting a new loan to buy more gas tanks to restock her store. She hopes that a loan will assist her in increasing the size of her business, attract new customers, and increase her sales. She also hopes that through the loan she can increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy gas tanks for selling.

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda is a married woman with no children. She lives with her husband in their own house that lacks both electricity and piped water. 

Brenda wants to start a charcoal selling business but she does not have enough capital to do so. For this reason, she turned to Yehu to ask for a loan of  10,000 KSH to buy sacks of charcoal to stock in a small store in her home. She anticipates good returns out of this investment and she hopes to grow her business and open more businesses in the future.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal to stock in a small store.

loans.name: Evelyn F

texts.en:
Evelyn is 32 years old, single, and has a child that is eleven years old.  She lives in West Point, and she stopped her education in the 8th grade. She has had a mini-shop in her community where she sells bread, cookies, soft drinks, mineral water, biscuits, and other items for the past five years.  She learned to sell from her mother, and Evelyn has been involved in this business for the past seven years. 

What she likes about her business is that she always makes a profit when she sells because of the location of her shop. With the profit, she buys goods and attends to her son's needs. She is requesting a loan to purchase more bread, soft drinks, mineral water, and biscuits for the business. Her future plan is to educate her son and to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more bread, soft drinks, mineral water, and biscuits for the business.

loans.name: Hafza

texts.en:
The husband of Ms Hafza, a mother of three, has been operating a general store for nine years now. Due to limited financial resources, this sole family income earner, shown in the photo, has been unable to expand his business, so his wife suggested he request a loan from Kashf Foundation to buy more grocery items such as packs of oil, salt, pulses, etc. In this way he will be able to better meet customer demand.

He hopes to earn more income and will utilize some of the profits to improve his home and increase his business capital.

loans.use: to buy more grocery items such as packs of oil, salt, pulses, etc.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 26 years old and married.  He lives with his wife and their one-and-a-half-year old son. They are happy to have this new member of their family. This is in fact their source of joy for their marriage.

Francis decided to set up a grocery store business in his home. In his store he sells staple household products like flour, toilet paper, rice, sugar, sodas, and detergents. His business has been running for three years, and he has a good customer base. 

He is requesting a loan of KES 40,000 to stock his store with food balers of flour, sacks of sugar, sacks of rice, and other fast-selling products, so that he can increase his sales. 

His goal is to continue to grow and eventually have a wholesale business, so that he can help his family financially.

loans.use: to stock his store with food balers of flour, sacks of sugar, sacks of rice, and other fast-selling products

loans.name: Rani

texts.en:
Rani is a hard-working, married woman.  She decided to continue working as a seamstress after she was married to help support her family. Overall she has fifteen years of seamstressing experience. She stitches for the people living near her home and uses the income to support her entire family. However, due to the lack of available funds, she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers.  

Rani has taken her first-time loan from Kashf for 20,000 PKR. She will use this loan to buy raw materials such as cloth, different colors of thread, laces, zippers, etc. to enhance revenues so she can generate a healthier source of income for her and her family. She is now providing a better education for her three children.

loans.use: to buy raw materials such as cloth, different colors of thread, laces, zippers, etc.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima has done milk production for 10 years.   After marriage, she feels that she should help her husband and family. 

Originally the business started with one cow, and later on, she was able to increase the number of animals. Now her home situation is on the horizon of improvement, and her four children are getting better health and schooling.

loans.use: to buy another cow.

loans.name: Azra

texts.en:
Ms. Azra is 37 years old, a hardworking and independent woman. She lives in Kamalia City in Punjab with her 3 children. The death of her husband five years ago was the hardest time of her life. No family member has come forward to support her in this desperate time. 

She has relied on utilizing her skills of stitching and embroidery. She has now successfully/efficiently been doing this business for the past 5 years. Two years ago she applied for the first loan, from Kashf Foundation, to enhance her business and she successfully paid back the loan within the given timeline. To further enhance her business by buying unstitched cloth from the the market and selling the finished/stitched dresses in the local communities, she has requested her 3rd loan of Rs 20,000 (Pakistani Rupees, PKR) from Kiva's partner Kashf Foundation.  
 
Ms. Azra has the ambition to provide her children with all the possible resources to get a better education and have the necessities of life.

loans.use: to buy unstitched cloth from the market and sell the finished/stitched dresses in the local communities.

loans.name: Sattan

texts.en: Ms. Sattan is a working woman with the skill of clay crockery. She started clay crockery work 10 years ago.  It is with this business that she was able to provide a better education and health facility to her children. She makes exciting new designs with her innovation and her customers like it. These designs and art are of great demand and she is willing to purchase more raw material and designs which will further enhance her business. She is also willing to search for new markets for her business. For that she needs capital, which she is taking from Kashf Foundation.

loans.use: to buy raw material, e.g. mud, color, etc.

loans.name: Amani

texts.en:
Amani is 27 years old. He is married and has 2 children, one is school age and the other is still young.

Amani owns rental houses, a business he started out three years ago. His wife operates a vegetable stall. Amani is requesting a loan in the amount of Ksh 50,000 to open a retail shop. He plans to purchase basic items such as sugar, tea leaves, flour, etc. to sell.

He wants to continue providing for his family.

loans.use: to purchase basic items such as sugar, tea leaves, flour, etc. to sell

loans.name: Mamuka

texts.en:
Mamuka is 44 years old. He lives in Khoni District with his 71-year-old mother. Mamuka owns a nut garden and does all the relevant seasonal agricultural works to ensure a good harvest. The nuts are sold in his village. He has requested loans from his local financial institutions several times without any success. His loan requests were rejected every time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for his family is the monthly pension of Mamuka’s mother and a small income earned by Mamuka from working as an artisan in the village. According to the government's estimations, the family belongs to the vulnerable poor category so they get monthly social assistance.

Mamuka requested a loan from Credo to start up his family business, and his loan request was approved. The start-up loan program provides start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions for country, rural poor who do not have access to credit products since they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With the loan, Mamuka will build a greenhouse. He will purchase building materials and construct it. Mamuka will sow different kinds of greens and tomatoes and sell them at a good price. This will increase the income of his family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family. Mamuka awaits your support.

loans.use: to build a greenhouse.

loans.name: Tinatin

texts.en:
Tinatin is 24 years old. She lives in the Martvili district, West Georgia with her parents and siblings. Tinatin requested loans from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was always rejected, because of  her low income and her family’s poor living conditions. 

The family is involved in a small-scale agricultural business. They run a family-owned dairy farm with two milk cows. Tinatin produces cheese and sells it in the village. In addition, they grow nuts and persimmons on the family-owned land. The family's average monthly income is 300 GEL ( Georgian Lari: 1 GEL = .60 USD). It is not enough to provide Tinatin and her family with adequate living conditions. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Tinatin has requested a loan from Credo to re-start her family business, which was stopped a couple of years ago because of financial problems. Her loan request was approved as part of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program provides credit for business start-up, and re-start-up with fewer conditions, to the country's rural poor. This population is often considered "high risk borrowers" because of low income, and they often do not have access to credit. With the credit, Tinatin will purchase chickens to start a poultry farm. She will place the chickens in a shed located in their yard, She will raise and sell the chickens for a higher price. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase chickens to start a poultry farm.

loans.name: Mishi

texts.en:
Mishi works hard to support her family. She is married and has a food vending business in the vicinity of Kisauni.

Mishi has requested a KES 20,000 loan through Yehu to buy ingredients for her business. She will be able to buy wheat flour, oil, and sugar. She has been in this business for almost two years now.

In the future, Mishi would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, oil, and sugar.

loans.name: Fareed

texts.en:
Fareed is 20 years old and he is from Gaza. He has owned a grocery store since 2010.

Fareed has asked Ryada for this youth loan in order to buy a display refrigerator and display shelves. With this loan he will display more goods and hopefully sell more and improve his income.

loans.use: to buy a display refrigerator and display shelves.

loans.name: Gomiti

texts.en:
Gomiti used his previous loan from Faulu Kenya to renovate his classrooms. He has managed to admit more pupils in the school, and he currently employs 15 teachers. 

He has requested a loan of 70,000 Kes to construct a kitchen and buy kitchen appliances. He also want to use the loan to buy beds, because he wants to provide boarding facilities.

loans.use: To construct a kitchen and buy beds for his school

loans.name: Abdullah

texts.en:
Abdullah is 22 years old from Gaza, and he is married. Abdullah wishes to open his own mini market.

He asked Ryada for this start up loan in order to buy the necessary goods and food to sell, and do some decorations for his mini market. Abdullah hopes that this loan will help him improve his income and thus his financial situation. 

Ryada's Startup Loan is exclusively for borrowers who are beginning new enterprises, not for existing projects. To qualify, a borrower must show a clear business plan and realistic potential for success. The borrower must also invest their own money and resources into at least 50 percent of the startup enterprise. Ryada believes strongly in the potential of these borrowers and grants them a three month grace period to help them get their business off the ground.

loans.use: to buy goods, food and some decorations for his mini market.

loans.name: Josephat

texts.en:
Josephat is a married man with seven children, five of whom are attending school. For the last 10 years, he has owned rental houses which have been providing him with a good income. He is married to Kwekwe and they live happily. His aim is to own several rental houses to earn more income. 

Josephat is requesting this loan to make repairs to some of the rooms in his rental houses. This will motivate more tenants to rent, since the rooms will look more attractive and comfortable in which to live. He thanks both Kiva and Yehu for the support he is receiving.

loans.use: to repair some of the rooms in his rental houses.

loans.name: Champs De Naboth Baco Group

texts.en:
Maloba, aged 54, is the chairman of the Community Bank named “Champs de Naboth”. It is composed of 5 members united in solidarity for receiving Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.

Maloba has been part of the micro-enterprise world since 1984. He sells galvanized sheet in details. He has acquired solid experience in this field. His business is located to the south west of Lubumbashi. Maloba has already received the MFI HOPE DRC loans and repaid them correctlysix times. The loan he’ll obtain next will be used to buy more goods to resell by retail with the goal of increasing his profits. His business generates a profit of US$100 per week. Maloba is married and the father of ten children whose ages vary between 12 and 24 years. Five of the children still go to school.

loans.use: to buy more goods to resell at a profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Elham Group

texts.en:
This group is called Elham, and consists of four ladies who live in Sana`a, Yemen. They took out a loan of 200,000 YER from AMB.

Elham is 30 years old and married. She lives in Sana`a, Yemen. She has education to the secondary school level. She is applying for a youth loan of 50,000 YER from AMB to buy construction materials for her house.

loans.use: to buy construction materials for her house.

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher is 39 years old and lives in the town of Mukono, Uganda. He is married and has four children who are all currently in school. For the past seven years, Christopher has been working hard to manage his drug store, which sells Panadol (acetaminophen), Pampers, creams, and other medicines. 

To help expand his business, Christopher has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stock like lotions and Panadol to sell and will help him generate greater profit to improve the standard of living of his clients and his family. Christopher hopes that in the future he will be able to have a very big drug store. 

Christopher is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Christopher who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more medicines like Panadol (acetaminophen) and lotions to sell.

loans.name: Kastriot

texts.en:
Kastriot, 25, is single and lives with his entire family. He is very ambitious and, although he is still a student, he was also able to open his own business last year. He owns a cafe/bar. At the beginning, business was very slow but now his business is growing and developing as he offers his customers different coffee and drinks. 

Kastriot is requesting a loan in order to renovate his café/bar and change the carpets. This loan will help him to improve the ambiance and make the café more comfortable for his customers, improving his business and increasing his income. His goal is to expand his business and secure his future.

He hopes, in the near future, to get married. Kastriot wants to thank all Kiva lenders!

loans.use: To renovate his café bar to change the carpets.

loans.name: Avdush

texts.en:
Avdush is twenty-three years old. He is living in a southern part of Kosovo in the Ashkali community. He is married and has three children between the ages of three and eight years old. Two of the children attend school currently. 

Avdush works as a lumberjack, cutting wood. He provides woodcutting services to those in his community in order to provide heat during the cold weather. He had originally started working together with his uncle; however he has now managed to work by himself. As a result of separating from his uncle, Aydush needs a loan in order to purchase a saw for himself. Through his work he helps his family and gives them everything they need. He is requesting a loan to buy a woodcutting machine. 

This loan will help to improve his business dramatically and, with the winter months and cold approaching, he will have a higher amount of demands and increase in the need for his services, therefore raising the income for his family. Aydush hopes to generate more income and secure a better life and education for his children. He appreciate all Kiva lenders!

loans.use: to buy a woodcutting machine.

loans.name: Ganimete

texts.en:
Ganimete is fifty-one years old. She is living in the southwestern part of Kosovo. She has seven children between the ages of nine and thirty years old. Her husband is a construction worker. 

They were able to build a new house for their family; however the money he generates is not enough to pay for the entire renovation of their home, as they are still in need of completing the second floor. Ganimete needs a loan in order to renovate the façade of her house and complete the renovations. The loan will help her to have a better life for her family, which is her ultimate goal. She is very thankful to all Kiva lenders!

loans.use: to finish the construction on her home.

loans.name: Xhejlane

texts.en:
Xhejlane is married. She is twenty-four years old with a one-year-old little boy. For more than eight years now she has been making handicraft items to sell. She works from her home and her clients are mostly women who are getting married and need items for their weddings. She also sells her crafts and goods in the market. In this way she earns her living from both sources, keeping a steady income. As she has said, she is satisfied with the income from this business. 

Xhejlane is requesting a loan in order to purchase material and tools for her work. She hopes in the future to be able to employ a staff member to assist her and make her business and time more efficient and she will be able to expand. This loan will help her to improve this business. Her goal is to expand  her business. She appreciates very much this support!

loans.use: To purchase material and tools for her work.

loans.name: Sanu Maya

texts.en:
Sanu Maya is 40 years-old. She is married and has 2 children, aged 19 and 12.  In 2008, she established her furniture making business. Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 4 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy woods and timber for her business. In the future, Sanu Maya plans to uplift the economic conditions of her family.  She thanks you for your support.

In Nepal, furniture is still made the old-fashioned way. Using little more than basic hand tools, skilled artisans form raw lumber into beautifully finished pieces of furniture. With precision and an eye for detail, furniture makers produce shelves, bed frames, and cabinet sets. With the help of a Kiva loan, a furniture maker is able to increase the volume of their lumber purchase or to hire additional labor. This additional leverage allows an entrepreneur to increase productivity and profitability.

loans.use: to buy wood and timbers.

loans.name: Dipa

texts.en:
Dipa is 29 years-old.  She is married and has one child, aged 11.  In 2010, she established her grocery store business.  Working 8 days a week and 12 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 5 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy grocery goods for her business. In the future, Dipa plans to uplift the economic conditions of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

loans.use: to buy grocery goods for her business

loans.name: Alfrida B.s.

texts.en:
Alfrida B.S., 42, is a mother of four children. She is married and lives at west point. Her children are between the ages of 9 and 22. They stay with her at home, and are in school. She has had this business for the past five years.
 
Alfrida sells ladies blouses and skirts. Some challenges she faces are the competition in the market. Her  customers are always flowing to her table, because she buys first class used clothes to sell. With the profits that she generate from the business, she buys more goods, and assists her husband with the home expenses. She has requested her third loan from BRAC Liberia to purchase more used clothes to increase her sales. Her plan for the future is to become a big business woman.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for the business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of used clothing to sell.

loans.name: Spartak

texts.en:
Spartak, a thirty-four-year old talented and a hard-worker Egyptian man, has been active in making pastries, cheese & spinach pies for one year in his outskirts Egyptian community in eastern Albania where he lives with his parents and all the siblings. He’s been busy all this past year and is very happy with the business progress and the income he’s been generating so far.

Spartak has requested a loan of 100,000 ALL (Albanian Leke) from VisionFund Albania to help him renovate the front entrance of his little pastry shop. He says he wants to save his income to build a decent restaurant for his family and to get married soon.

Being aware that this loan and Spartak’s information will be published on Kiva for financial support from lenders, he wants to thanks people in advance for their kindness.

loans.use: to renovate the front entrance of a little pastry shop.

loans.name: Amie

texts.en:
Amie is 37, married, and has three children who live with her at west point. They are all in school.

Amie has a table in the market where she sells (country cloth) lappers, men's shirts, men's trousers, and ladies blouses. She has been involved in this business for the past seven years. She started her business with a little income that she has been saving. She learn to sell from a Ghanian business man, that she worked for. With the quality material that she sells, she makes a profit everyday. She uses the profits to improve the business and to help with the house hold expenses. She is requesting this loan  to purchase lappers, men's shirts, men's trousers, and ladies' blouses for the business. Her plan for the future is to educate her children, and to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase lappers, men's shirts, men's trousers, and ladies' blouses for the business.

loans.name: Hatixhe

texts.en:
A rural villager located in the south-central Albania, Hatixhe is a 60 year-old mother of six children. Some of her children are still dependent and go to school. She has been farming on her farmland and planting potatoes & grains and practicing animal husbandry as the main income source for long time now. With her current business, Hatixhe earns US$4 per day and is able to save US$2 daily. In addition to all this, she has been looking after her husband who has been paralyzed for almost ten years.

With a lack of money for her business, Hatixhe is applying for her second loan with VisionFund Albania. She will use this loan to replace the roofing of their house. The roof currently leaks and rain water is getting inside.
 
This loan will be a great help to their family and Hatixhe and her husband thank all lenders at Kiva.

loans.use: to replace the roofing of their house; at the moment the roof leaks and rain water is getting inside.

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en: Marlyn is 36 years old and lives in the Philippines with her husband and six children. For the last five years, she has earned a living by providing motorela (or motorcycle) services with her husband working as the driver. She is requesting a loan for PHP 5,000 to pay for maintenance of their motorcycle. Marlyn joined HSPFI earlier this year and in the future hopes to improve her services.

loans.use: to pay for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

loans.name: Bartolome

texts.en:
Bartolome is 66 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married, with two children. 

Bartolome is providing motorela, or motorcycle, services. He has had this business for eight years. He requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to pay for the maintenance of his motorcycle.

Bartolome has been a member of HSPFI since 2012.  In the future, Bartolome hopes to improve his services.

loans.use: to pay for the maintenance of his motorcycle.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is married, with four children. She is 54 years old and lives in Bañadero, Ozamis City. 

Gloria buys and sells stuffed toys for a living, and she has had this business for three years. Every month she earns PHP 5,000 from it. 

She has requested a loan of PHP 6,000 to purchase more stuffed toys to sell. Gloria joined GDMPC in 2007. 

In the future, she hopes to increase her savings for the future needs of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stuffed toys to sell.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther, aged 25, lives at Kakata. She stopped her education in the 4th grade. She is single and has a child who is 2 years old and is in school. Esther has been managing her provision shop for the past ten years. She sells washing soap, bath soap, vita, rice sugar, flour salt, hair grease, and other items. Some difficulties she faces are the unstable prices at the market because of the exchange rate, USD to (Liberian dollars)LD. However, because of the good location of her shop and the way she interacts with her customers, she makes a profit every day. 

She is proud of her business because it makes her feel independent, and she is  able to educate her child. She has requested this loan in order to purchase more rice, washing soap, bath soap, biscuits, hair grease and flour for the business. Her plans in the future are to educate her child and have a store.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, washing soap, bath soap, biscuits, hair grease and flour for her business.

loans.name: Irma

texts.en:
This is Irma, 56, a resident of Caloocan, Philippines. She is married to Harold, a worker abroad, and she is a mother to her children. She manages the family household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Irma maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are depending on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 2000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP20, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Irma hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams of having a good life for her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and merchandise/products needed in her business.

loans.name: Damdinbazar

texts.en:
Mr. Damdinbazar is 39 years old. He lives with his wife and three children in a ger ( Mongolian yurt ), in Songinohairhan district, in the capital city of Mongolia. His wife's name is Erdenebileg. She stays at a home. His older son is a college student and his two younger children go to the secondary school. 

He started a taxi service business in 2008. Now his business is sustainable and he has many regular customers. But Damdinbazar's monthly income does not usually meet his family's necessities. He wants to expand his own taxi service business. He would like to buy a new car for his business. He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: to pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en: Myrna is 41 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has 5 children. Myrna has a food/retail shop or sari-sari store where she buys & sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products & beverages. She had this business for 6 years. She has requested a loan for  5,000 PHP to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks & beverages. Myrna has been a member of HSPFI since 2012. In the future, Myrna hopes to improve her business for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Kembang Kertas Group

texts.en:
Although the group earned good profits from their last loan, they are requesting a new one because they are strongly motivated to become successful in their pig-raising businesses through the purchase of superior piglets.

Ni Nengah will use her portion of the loan to buy three superior piglets to raise and breed as she pursues her goal of becoming a piglet-seller in her village. She hopes MUK and KIVA will support her and the group, not only for the loan but for training also.

loans.use: to buy three superior piglets.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia is an active member of PMPC. She is 49 years old, married and the mother of five adult-age children and one minor.  She lives in Gabayan, Lazi, Siquijor where she has earned a living for more than five years by running a sari-sari (or variety) store where she earns PHP 2,000 a month. She is requesting a loan to buy additional groceries to sell to her customers. She plans to use the profits earned from this loan to pay everyday expenses and her children's school fees.

loans.use: to buy additional groceries to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Ely

texts.en:
Ely is from Labo, Ozamiz City. She is 50 years old and married, with four children. 

To make a living, Ely plants, harvests, and sells bananas. Ely has engaged in her business for 10 years, and she earns PHP 3,000 a month. In 2007, Ely joined GDMPC. 

Ely is requesting a loan of PHP 5,500 that will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, such as manure.

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.en:
Esperanza is 48 years old and has 7 children. Esperanza is married and has 3 children who are in school.

Esperanza is in the agricultural business of pig fattening in the Philippines. She requested a 25,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. Esperanza has been pig fattening for 5 years now, and has borrowed 11 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Esperanza would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy and sell dry goods business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 5 years. Evelyn earns more income from food vending. She is borrowing 15,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell for her business.

Evelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of her loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine works hard to support her family. Josephine is married and has a variety store business in the Philippines.

Josephine requested an 18,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her variety store. Josephine has been in this business for 15 years.

In the future, Josephine would like to save enough to improve her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 37 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Jocelyn is borrowing 29,500 PHP through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Jocelyn has been raising pigs for one year and also earns additional income from her photocopier business. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream - to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Davaasambuu

texts.en: Mr. Davaasambuu is 58 years old and lives with his wife and 2 sons in a Yurt, in Uvs province, Mongolia. He and his son have been operating a car repair shop since 2000. They have been living in Uvs province over 20 years. His wife is on a pension and her health is well. They have built a new workplace for their new car wash and tire repair shop. He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to buy equipment for the car wash and tire repair shop. He is a hard working and honest man.

loans.use: to buy equipment for his car wash and tire repair shop.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en: Thelma is a 45-year old resident of Labo, Ozamis City. Thelma provides for her 2 children from the little amount of 5,000 PHP she gains monthly from her own piggery business. She has been operating the business for 3 years as an aid to the income gained from her husband. However since 2007, she's been a member of GDMPC, and she has applied for a loan at GDMPC micro finance of 3,000 PHP to buy feeding supplies. Thelma wants to make expansion to her business one day.

loans.use: to buy feeding supplies.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en: Lilia is from Pobalcion 3, Clarin. She is 31 years old. Lilia is married and has 3 children. To make a living, Lilia owns & operates a banana plantation business. Lilia been in business for 5 years and earns 5,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2010, Lilia joined GDMPC. She is requesting a loan of 12,500 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.

loans.name: Bun Lestari Group

texts.en:
Often called Island of the Gods, Bali is predominantly Hindu, and this group of residents from Sangketan village have joined together to work with MUK to secure funding to buy piglets and feed for them to eat. Many housewives in Bali raise pigs as a way to help support their families. One problem is that most of them do not know the correct way of raising livestock. To improve their skills, they have joined a group where they can exchange information and apply for a loan from MUK.

Ni Wayan, 37, is a housewife who is head of the Bun Lestari loan group, which is requesting a loan to buy three piglets and feed. Six months after buying the pigs, they will be ready to sell and the money they bring in will help support families. One member of this group was sick and could not attend this meeting. She is represented here by her son.

loans.use: to buy three piglets and feed for them to eat.

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda is 73 years old and married with 3 children. Florenda works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 25,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell.

Florenda has borrowed and paid 27 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 12 years and also earns an income from fishing. Florenda aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: buy additional stock to sell

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 10 years. Gloria earns more income from her general store.

Gloria is borrowing 29,500 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional fish to sell for her fish vending business. Gloria has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Herminia

texts.en:
Herminia is married with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Herminia is 42 years old and has 3 children who are in school.

Herminia has a buy and sell dry goods business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 10 years. Herminia requested a 20,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell.

In the future, Herminia would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy and sell banana business in the Philippines. Jean has been in this business for 20 years. She earns more income from farming sugarcane and dried fish vending. She is borrowing 12,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional stocks of banana to sell for her business.

Jean has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of banana to sell

loans.name: Sari Madu Group

texts.en:
The Sari Madu group received their third loan of 22,5M IDR with a total of 15 members. The head of the group has been replaced by other member, Ni Luh. They also have new member, named Ni Putu.

Ni Luh wants to use her loan to purchase piglets and feed. She will keep the pigs for 5 months for fattening. To reduce the cost of feed, she gives the pigs a mixed feed made from various kinds of leaves. She has a dream to renovate her kitchen from the profit of this business.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla is married and has five children. She is 48 years old and lives in the Philippines. Perla has had a coconut production business for six years, and every month she earns 3,000 PHP from this work. 

Perla has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer. She has been a member of GDMPC since 2011. In the future, Perla hopes to allow her children to finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en:
Mrs Oyun is 42 years old and lives with husband and three children in a ger in Arhangai province, Mongolia. Her husband, Enhbaatar, is 42 years old. He works a repairman in a private company. Her daughter, Tuvsghintugs, is 19 years old. She is a college student. Her son, Chubo, is 12 years old. He is a secondary school student. Her younger son, Janlawzogzol, is 5 years old. He is joining a kindergarden. 

Mrs Oyun started her business in 2011 as meat retail at a rental counter on the black market. She has had many customers, and improved her business' net profit. She is planning to expand her business to wholesale meat. She is a modest and hardworking person. She is asking for a 2 000 000 MNT loan to buy more goods. She will buy the goods for the business using 500.000 MNT. She will use rest of the loan to pay a school premium for her older daughter's education.

loans.use: to buy more goods for her business offer and to pay premium for her older daughter.

loans.name: Erdenebileg

texts.en:
Mr. Erdenebileg is 42 years old and lives with his wife and his three children in a ger, Mongolian yurt, in Uvs province of Mongolia. His wife's name is Dulamsuren. She is 34 years old and works for a private company as a shop assistant. Her monthly salary is 250,000 - 300,000 MNT. His three children go to the secondary school. 

Mr. Erdenebileg started a make-a-Mongolian-yurt business in 2003-2012. The make-a-Mongolian-yurt business is a seasonal business. He started a transportation business a short time ago. He would like to buy a new hybrid car for his business. The price of the hybrid car is 6,500,000 MNT. He has prepaid 3,500,000 MNT for the car. Now he is requesting 3,000,000 MNT to pay off the rest. He is a hardworking and calm man.

loans.use: To pay off the rest of the hybrid car cost

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: Gina regularly attends meetings of PMPC. She is married and the mother of three school-age children. Gina earns a living by running a grocery store where she sells food and drinks. She has been in this business for the last year and earns PHP 1,500 a month. She took out a previous loan from PMPC to buy additional items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the profits earned from this loan to support the basic needs of her family and pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to buy groceries and drinks to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en: Elvie is an active individual member of PMPC. She is single, and a resident of Candanay Sur, Siquijor, Siquijor. Her primary source of livelihood is sari-sari store business which she has operated for a period of 6 years. She earns, from the business, the amount of PHP 2,500 a month.  She took another loan from PMPC to purchase grocery stocks to sell and a piglet to raise and to be sold in the future. She wishes to have savings in preparation for her future.

loans.use: to purchase grocery stocks and a piglet to raise.

loans.name: Serason Indah Group

texts.en:
As a housewife in Bali, it has become commonplace to have pigs at home, as well as a side job also to support the family economy. But the problem is, most of them do not know how to raise pigs properly and correctly to get the pigs in good condition. For that they join a regular group to exchange ideas and enhance their capabilities. In addition they can also get funding from MUK to purchase piglets.

Ni Ketut, 44, a housewife, is a group leader of Serason Indah. The group provides the opportunity to improve their individual abilities in terms of raising pigs and raising capital for the business. The loans will be used to purchase piglets and feed. In a period of 5 months,  a pig will be ready to be sold and the profits from this venture will be used entirely to support the economy of the family.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and feed.

loans.name: Odhuu

texts.en: Mrs Odhuu is 26 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a small house, in Orhon province. Her husband is 26 years old and he operates a construction business. She helped her mother in business between 2000 to 2009. Her mother sells organic dairy products. She started her own organic dairy trade business in 2009. She rents a place to sell organic dairy products in a market. She is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan to buy organic dairy reserves and then to sell them. This loan is her first request. She is a hardworking and friendly woman.

loans.use: to buy organic dairy reserves and then sell them.

loans.name: Ligaya

texts.en:
Ligaya is from Kinuman, Ozamis City. She is 33 years old. Ligaya is married and has 3 children. To make a living, she plants, harvests and sells coconuts. For 3 years, Ligaya has worked at this business, and she gets about 3,000 PHP a month for these activities. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. 

In 2011, Ligaya joined GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.

loans.name: Tuul

texts.en:
Mrs Tuul is 44 years old and lives with her husband and 4 children in a Ger, in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. Her husband helps with her business and her eldest son is a college student. Her other children are in secondary school and kindergarden.  

Mrs Tuul started her clothes selling business in 2010, with a working capital of 1,000,000  MNT. Now her working capital was increased to 3,000,000 MNT. Her business is sustainable. She would like to expand her business by increasing the variety of goods she offers for sale. She needs 2,400,000 MNT to pay tuition fees for her son. She is a humble person who says ''My dream is to build my own house on my land''.

loans.use: to pay tuition fees for her son.

loans.name: Genie

texts.en:
This is Genie, 57, a resident of Caloocan, Philippines. She is married to Roel and a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Genie operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails in groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Genie hopes to give her children a good and quality education and dreams to have a good life through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to purchase more grocery items to sell.

NWTF is re-listing Helen's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
This is Angelina, who is 55 years old and a resident of Dasmarinas, Cavite, Philippines. She is a widow and mother to her children. Together with her children, she manages their household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Angelina operates a computer rental shop. In the Philippines, very few people own their own computers. Thus there is a need for them, especially for students who need to do their research and papers. She rents out computers by the hour and offers printing and typing services. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 Philippine in sales every day.

To help her continue operations, she is requesting a PHP 30,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy new computer units, spare parts, and accessories needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Angelina hopes to have a deeper relationship with God. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of their work every week.  It is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for computer parts and supplies needed in her business

loans.name: Diasyre

texts.en: For the last four years, Diasyre, a 25-year-old married mother of two children, has made a living by operating a general store where she sells a variety of food and home-use products. She earns PHP 3,000 a month from her work. Diasyre joined GDMPC, in 2011 and is requesting a loan for PHP 3,500 to buy more items to sell, including candies, shampoo and soaps. She plans to save the additional revenue generated by this loan so that it is available in case of future emergencies.

loans.use: to buy new items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is an active individual member of PMPC. She is single with 2 school-age children. Her economic activity is a sari-sari store dealing grocery stocks and drinks. Evelyn has operated the business for a period of 2 years having an average monthly income of 3,000 PHP.  She took another loan from PMPC to purchase additional grocery stocks and drinks for sale. She will used the profit to support the daily needs of her children and especially their education.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery stocks and drinks for sale

loans.name: Munhzul

texts.en: Ms. Munhzul is 37 years old and lives with her husband and 3 children in a small house in Ulaanbaatar. She has been working as a literary teacher in the local high school for 12 years. Her husband, Batgerel, has worked in a local private company as a woodman for many years. So he is famous in his company. They have a medium standard of living. Ms. Munhzul is requesting a 6,000,000 MNT loan to buy a hybrid car, that works by gas, a Daewoo Magnus. They need to carry their children between home to school by car. She is hardworking and helpful. They are very happy that they will have a first car.

loans.use: To buy a hybrid car, that works by gas to carry their children between home to school by car

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem, 50-year old, is a married entrepreneur of Poblacion, Clarin with 5 children and is earning from his transport service business. It has been going for almost 5 years now and he earn 8,000 PHP a month. To improve business, he is borrowing an amount of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC micro credit, which he just joined recently, to obtain accessories and tires. Before long, he’s hopeful of the possibility of expanding his business.

loans.use: to obtain accessories and tires.

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en:
Luzminda is an active micro-finance member of PMPC. She's been a member since 2011. She is 58 years old, and a single mom with 2 adult-age children. She has been engaged in making and selling snacks for a period of 3 years, having monthly average earnings of PHP 2,600.  

Luzminda has taken previous loans from PMPC to support her livelihood activities. Now she is taking another loan to purchase raw ingredients to make snacks. She wants to use the profits to support the daily needs and to have savings in preparation for her old-age life in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients to make snacks.

loans.name: Andres

texts.en: Support a young Colombian business owner!  Andres lives in Miami and has a double life. When he is not working long hours as a parking attendant, he does what he likes most – cooking. Andres’ specialties include “pan de bono” and homemade “arepas”. He sells these traditional Colombian meals to his friends and neighbors and, because they are in such high demand, he has decided to turn this into a formal business. His mother helps him bake the products early in the morning and then he distributes the meals at lunch time. Andres’ dream is to have a food truck where he can sell his delicious Colombian meals. throughout the city.  He needs a loan to invest in a marketing campaign in order for people to know about his products, to get more clients,  to increase production, and ultimately, to be able to quit his regular job and dedicate himself full time to his passion.  Help Andres take the next step in his business.

loans.use: to pay for a marketing campaign

loans.name: Ulziibat

texts.en:
Ulziibat is 37 years old. She lives with her husband and 2 sons in Orhon province of Mongolia. Her husband works at a mining company in the summertime. In the wintertime, he produces shoes at home. Her 2 sons go to secondary school. Ulziibat is a hardworking and good natured person.

Mrs. Ulziibat has been running an organic fruit and vegetable retailing business since 2011, with working capital of 2,000,000 MNT. Now her working capital has increased to 3,000,000 MNT. Her business has improved and now she sells many kinds of organic fruits and vegetables. She imports high quality products. Her next goals are to enlarge her counter and then to open her own wholesale shop. 

She requests 6,500,000 MNT to import more organic apples, watermelons and tomatoes from Selenge province to increase her working capital, then her transport costs will decrease.

loans.use: To import more organic apples, watermelons and tomatoes from Selenge province to increase her working capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides for an agricultural business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy groceries for a grocery store business.

loans.name: Juan

texts.en: Support Juan in his efforts to improve the quality of customer service in the taxi industry in Miami. Juan is originally from the Dominican Republic, but has been living in Miami with his wife and two kids for a long time. Juan saw there weren’t enough taxis to meet Miami’s busy tourist needs. Seeing this opportunity, he started a small fleet called Gold Taxi Services. What really drives Juan is a strong belief in the importance of customer service and everything he does with his company is focused on delivering the best quality of service and comfort for his clients. Juan is hardworking and tries to  view the obstacles that appear in his life as challenges that he can overcome. He is looking for a loan to increase the number of cars in his fleet, to increase production and to come closer to his goal of becoming the number one taxi service in customer satisfaction in Miami. Please help Juan get one step closer to his dream!

loans.use: to add more cars to his taxi fleet

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fresh fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy fruit for fruit-selling business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
This is Teresita, 55, a resident of Caloocan, Philippines. She is single and a mother to her children. She, together with her children, manages her household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Teresita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, Teresita is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Teresita hopes to give her children a good and quality education and dreams to have a good life through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Shakeela's Group

texts.en:
Shakeela is a 30-year-old hardworking woman. She lives in Punjab, Pakistan with her husband and son. Her husband is a laborer but his income is too low to meet the basic expenses of his family.  

Since 2006, Shakeela, by stitching clothes, has helped her husband to meet the household and children's education expenses. Now she is interested in continuing to grow her business by purchasing a new tailoring machine and tailoring materials like thread and clothing. For that reason, as a member of an eight-person lending group, she has requested a loan from Kiva partner BRAC Pakistan. 

With the profits, she wants to build a new room in her house. Her dream of life is to live happily with her family in their own house. She is very thankful to KIVA and BRAC and says that BRAC is working very well and the staff is very co-operative.

loans.use: To purchase a new tailoring machine and tailoring materials.

loans.name: Sherlita

texts.en: Sherlita has been an active micro finance member of PMPC since 2011.  She is 48 years old and widowed with one adult-age and four school-age children.
